metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Media's effect on shaping knowledge, awareness risk perceptions and communication practices of pandemic COVID-19 among pharmacists Media's effect on shaping knowledge, awareness risk perceptions and communication practices of pandemic COVID-19 among pharmacists

affiliation.institution: Jordan University of Science and Technology

abstract.text: Background Coronavirus disease , an infection of the zoonotic 5 coronavirus, is presenting a healthcare challenge around the globe. This study aims to 6 assess the levels of disease knowledge and risk perception among pharmacists. We 7 also recognize predictors of risk perception and perceived media roles. Methods This 8 is a questionnaire-base cross-sectional study. The questionnaire was developed on a 9 web-based platform and invitations were sent to pharmacists nationwide to participate 10 in the study using social media applications. Results A total of 486 pharmacists 11 participated in this study, where females were dominant (78.6%, n= 382). Most 12 (40.4%, n=198) pharmacists scored 4 out of 5 in basic disease knowledge, and more 13 than half were able to recognize common methods of spread. Risk was highly 14 perceived among participants, and was predicted by gender, living area, and having 15 children (p<0,05). Frequency of watching the media and sources of information also 16 influenced both risk perception and perceived media roles. Conclusion Disease 17 awareness among pharmacists, as well as risk perception must be considered for 18 effective risk communication planning. The role of media in shaping perceptions 19 should also be carefully studied to encourage compliance with government 20 containment measures and engagement in preventive behaviors. 21 22 51 include vaccine administration, such as during the H1N1 outbreak, drug distribution, 52 health education, and providing direct patient care under exceptional conditions 13,14 . 53 Therefore, ensuring sufficient knowledge and awareness of pandemics among 54 pharmacists, in addition to recognizing factors shaping their risk perceptions and 55 communication practices, are vital for the prevention and control of disease. 56 Media was found to facilitate obtaining of up to date available information improving 57 knowledge, awareness, and practices of both healthcare workers and general public 15 . 58 Also, it plays a key role in communication between researchers, scientists, public 59 health experts and funding agencies, for effective and rapid global response 15,16 . The 60 emergence of the COVID-19 outbreak grabbed the attention of media news, press, 61 and social media pages. However, there are too many sources and sites through which 62 any one can obtain information, and many of them are not credible which resulted in 63 misinformation and difficulties to distinguish between rumors and reality. Thus, 64 health care workers and the public must refer to trustworthy sources and information 65 regarding COVID-19 such as WHO which provided social media teams and technical 66 risk communication to respond and track rumors and myths 11 . Additionally, 67 government and health care facilities should provide transparent and clear 68 communication with health care workers, staff, and public regarding COVID-19 69
outbreak. This study aimed to assess media role on shaping pharmacists' knowledge, 70

body_text.text: After the pandemic of two human pathogenic respiratory coronavirus; the severe 25 acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) 1 and the Middle East 26 respiratory syndrome coronavirus ( MERS-CoV) 2 , a third novel zoonotic human 27 coronavirus (COVID-19) has emerged in December 2019. Through its crossing 28 species, it was found to cause a cluster of frequently severe respiratory infection cases 29 in human population that greatly resemble the clinical manifestation of viral 30 pneumonia 3-5 . While first reports from initial investigations of this outbreak in 31 Wuhan, China indicated that most cases are associated with wildlife animals and a 32 seafood market where these patients had worked or visited, and the nonexistent of 33 COVID-19 transmission between humans and if so, it could not spread easily between 34 them 6 . However, now it is clear that such spreading occurs 7 and many confirmed 35 cases were identified among contacts with patients with COVID-19 and among 36 healthcare professionals, and most of these cases lack direct contact with this animal's 37 market. Thus, transmission between human populations has been confirmed in china 7 38 and many other countries 8,9 and has rapidly evolved into a global health emergency 39 as declared by World health Organization (WHO) 10 74 This is a cross-sectional study based on self-reported questionnaire. The questionnaire 75 was developed on a web-based platform to facilitate completion and collection of data 76 during the quarantine period. Invitations were sent to pharmacists nationwide to 77 participate in the study using social media applications. The link to the survey 78 questionnaire was included in the sent invitations. Pharmacists were informed prior to 79 their participation that their participation is anonymised, voluntary, and that their data 80 will be treated as confidential. Also, a brief description about the study purpose was Questionnaire Development 86 Scales for measuring perceived risk towards COVID19 and perceived role of media 87 have been developed, for the most part, in studies relating perceived role of media to 88 the perceived risk of acute infectious diseases. We developed a set of main ideas and 89 primary items directly relevant to our topic were based on current scientific literature.

The primary items were reviewed by seven experts in the field of clinical pharmacy 91 and public health who were required to provide feedback and suggest necessary 92 changes in order to establish both face and content validity of the survey 93 questionnaire. Afterwards, the reliability of the questionnaire was established using a 94 pilot test by collecting data from 20 pharmacists not included in the study sample.

They were asked to fill in the questionnaire individually and were encouraged to think 96 loudly and to speak what they meant by each answer and how they understood each 97 question. Responses were voice recorded and questions were adjusted accordingly. (1.00 -1.66), medium score ( 1.67-2.33), and high score (2.34 -3). These were ranked 111 as "Third", "Second", and "First" respectively.

The 5-point Likert scale was used to measure pharmacists perceived role of media, by 113 giving each item of the questionnaire one point (Strongly Disagree=1, Neutral=3, and 114 Strongly Agree=5) to analyze the results as follows: low score (1.00-2.33), medium 115 score (2.34 -3.67), and high score (3.68 -5.00). These were ranked "Third", 116 "Second", and "First" respectively.

118 Data were analyzed using IBM SPSS software version 24. Data were described using 119 frequencies and percentages. Chi-square was used to analyze differences between 120 categorical variables. Student's t-test was used to compare the means between two 121 groups. A p-value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Demographic characteristics 125 Participants' demographics are shown in Table 1 Table 3 shows the perceived risk of COVID-19 infection among pharmacists. The 143 average (±SD) risk perception score for participants was high for almost all 144 statements. For example, pharmacists were concerned about the risk of community 145 spread (2.93 ± 0.33) and getting infected during work in healthcare settings (2.56 ± 146 0.79). They also believed this disease is more dangerous than winter flu (2.64 ± 0.68).
However, scores were also high for positive risk perceptions, such as high recovery The perceived role of media briefing on COVID-19 was also assessed (Table 4) .

Pharmacists scored high in agreement with the following media roles: spreading Several factors predicted an increased risk perception among pharmacists (Table 5) . 158 For example, female gender, living in a city, and having children were all associated 159 with an increased perception of COVID-19 risk (P<0.05). Those who watched the 160 media weekly, compared to daily or monthly, also had higher risk perceptions. Other Risk perception of pandemics can predict compliance with preventive measures and 190 tendency to seek treatment or vaccination 18, 19 . Furthermore, identifying how risk is 191 perceived is important for creating risk communication plans 20 . Unlike other reports, 192 where female gender has been linked to more worry and engagement in preventive 193 and treatment-seeking behaviors 21,22 , we find males to have higher perception of risk. 194 Additionally, living in city areas, having children, and working in a hospital pharmacy 195 are all associated with a higher perceived risk of the coronavirus pandemic. Other 196 studies also report a strong association between age and risk perception. For example, 197 Jacob et al found that younger age (16) (17) (18) (19) (20) (21) (22) (23) (24) predicted higher disease concern 20 . In 198 contrast, a study of 1,290 US adults showed no association between age and 199 engagement in protective measures during the H1N1 influenza pandemic 23 . In our 200 study, those below 25 and above 35 years had the highest risk perception, but the 201 difference was not significant. This could be due to lower participation of younger age 202 groups (<20 years) in both our study and the study from the US. Distinction between 203 city and rural areas can also be justified by the variation in case numbers between 204 different geographic areas 23 . Therefore, we expect higher concern about viral spread 205 in the more crowded cities. Jacobs also finds no association between having elderly 206 and children in the household and disease concerns. This is however inconsistent with 207 results from a similar study, where more household members predicted increased 208 precautionary activities 23 . It is justified as children can be more susceptible to viral

As April 21 st 2020, the 40 confirmed number of cases was 2,555,760 with about 75,254 new cases globally, and 41 these numbers are increasing continuously around the world, with the USA emerging 42 as the new COVID-19 hotspot 11 . 43 It is observed that suspected COVID-19 cases are usually seeking medical help from 44 available healthcare facilities near to them such as emergency department, 45 pharmacies, and other health organizations. Therefore, health care professionals and 46 front-line staff available in hospitals and other health organizations should be ready 47 and well-prepared with the best available information and protocols to treat any 48 patient with suspected COVID-19 infection even if presenting with minimal notice 12 . 49 Pharmacists have been a first point of contact for healthcare provision and have 50 historically performed major roles during pandemics and viral outbreaks. Those perceptions and attitudes during the pandemic of COVID-19.

FIGREF2.text: 81 provided. The average completion time of the survey was 10 minutes. Ethical 82 approval for conducting the study was obtained from the Institutional Review Board 83 (IRB) (reference number: 21/132/2020).

FIGREF4.text: The final survey contained 29 items including closed ended questions with responses 99 based on Likert scale and multiple-choice formats. It consisted of five parts: 100 demographics, knowledge, and perceived risks and media role. Demographic 101 information included gender, age, experience (years), level of education, work setting, 102 monthly income, and marital status. Knowledge about COVID -19 was assessed using 103 questions on basic knowledge and factual knowledge. Basic knowledge part 104 consisted of 5 questions that included name, origin (place and vector), incubation 105 period, and diagnosis. These were scored by assigning one point for each correct 106 answer. Factual knowledge included questions on mode of transmission, signs and 107 symptoms, and risk factors. The 3-point Likert scale was used to measure pharmacists 108 perceived risk towards COVID19 by giving each item of the questionnaire one point 109 (Disagree=1, Neutral=3, and Agree=4) to analyze the results as follows: low score110

FIGREF5.text: correct answers of questions that assessed basic knowledge on COVID-132 19 are shown inTable 2. Almost all the pharmacists had knowledge related to133 COVID-19 place of origin and incubation period. Most of the participants (n=198, 134 40.4%) scored 4 out of 5 of basic knowledge about COVID-19 pandemic. Almost all 135 of the participants answered that coughing and sneezing is the main mode of 136 transmission, fever and shortness of breath are the most common signs and symptoms 137 and that older patients and patients with chronic diseases and weakened immunity are 138 at higher risk for contacting COVID-19. However, 68.2 % (n=334) of participants 139 answered that the infection can be transmitted from person to person and only 13.5% 140 (n=66) answered that headache is a common sign of infection.

FIGREF11.text: 161 predictors included work setting and sources of information. Gender, work setting, 162 frequency of watching the media, sources of information also predicted the perceived 163 media role among pharmacists (p<0.05). coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, originating from Wuhan, China, 167 presents a global healthcare crisis 15 . In this study, we aimed to assess the knowledge 168 of pharmacists about disease spread, symptoms, and susceptibility. We also identify 169 predictors of the COVID-19 risk perception and perceived media roles during the 170 outbreak. 171 172Generally, social media was the main source for coronavirus-related information in 173 around half of the population. This was followed by local and international channels.

FIGREF12.text: Such sources were used daily to weekly by most pharmacists. These results are in175    accordance with a study that compared knowledge and practices among healthcare176 workers during the 2012 Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak 17 . 177 Pharmacists compromised 4.6% of the study population, which also included 178 physicians (41.4%), nurses (33.3%), and technicians (20.7%). Social media ranked 179 second among sources of MERS-related information used by healthcare providers 180 (45%), only preceded by seminars and workshops (48%). Other media outlets used 181 were newspapers and magazines (18%), and radio and television (37%). However, 182 among pharmacists, books and articles led the sourced of MERS-related information, 183 followed by workshops and seminars (38%) and posters and pamphlets (38%). Media 184 sources of information among pharmacists included social media (33%), radio and 185 television (27%), and newspapers and magazines (22%). Two other similar studies on 186MERS had consistent results, as social media and the internet were the most common 187 sources of information among healthcare providers18,19 .

FIGREF14.text: 209infections. Nonetheless, it is worth to note the difference in disease vulnerability 210 among children between H1N1 and the novel coronavirus. Whereas morbidity and 211 mortality is increased in the former, COVID-19 appears to take a milder watching media predicted both risk perception and perceived media 215 roles among pharmacists. This is strongly supported by previous reports from the216 MERS, SARS, and H1N1 outbreaks. For example, a study from South Korea had 217 shown a positive association between social media exposure and the formation of risk 218 perception during the latest MERS outbreak 25 . Moreover, Chang et al. reported a 219 correlation between watching H1N1-related television news and formation of public 220 risk perception about the outbreak 26 . While this may support the role of media in 221 effective risk communication, it is worth noticing the effects media create on mental 222wellbeing during a pandemic. In its advice for coping with coronavirus stress, WHO 223 recommends limiting news exposure that may cause upset or agitation 27 . respiratory droplets and person-to-person contact7,32 . The most 230 common symptoms, including fever, cough, fatigue or myalgia 4 were also recognized 231 by almost all participants. However, only 13.6% and 41.6% correctly identified 232 headache and diarrhea, respectively, as disease symptoms. Those symptoms, in 233 addition to nausea, may be the early clinical manifestation among coronavirus patients

FIGREF15.text: Reports from earlier pandemics show similar satisfactory levels of disease 235 knowledge among pharmacists. However, they remain inferior compared to other 236 healthcare providers, possibly due to less involvement in hospital patient care. For 237 example, when Albarrak et al scored knowledge related to MERS, pharmacists 238 (88.9%) ranked third to physicians (95.7%) and technicians (91.4%) in having 'Good' 239 disease knowledge 17 . Highest scores (94.4%) were attained for questions related to 240 vaccine availability in the market and methods of viral transmission. Most (94.4%) 241 pharmacists showed positive attitudes towards the MERS crisis, with all (100%) 242 agreeing that protective masks, gloves, and googles should be used when dealing with 243 patients, and that patients should be kept in isolation. This was in accordance with 244 study results from Saudi and Vietnamese populations where attitudes towards wearing 245 protective gear were also positive 33-35 . The majority of pharmacists have also shown 246 positive MERS practices, including washing hands with soap and water (72.2%), 247 throwing used tissues in the trash (100%), and covering nose and mouth during 248 sneezing and coughing (77.8%). However, only 27.8% reported wearing face masks 249 in the crowds. Another small study of 35 healthcare providers (HCP) in hospitals and 250 community pharmacies was conducted during the H1N1 pandemic 36 . The study 251 assessed the knowledge of HCP on the transmission, prevention, and management of 252 H1N1. Pharmacists' knowledge was suboptimal among all three aspects. Additionally, 253 most participants (64%) were uninformed about the drug management of H1N1 or the 254 side effects (92.5%) of recommended antivirals.

FIGREF16.text: how people respond to and engage in preventive behaviors. Pharmacists had 260 good levels of COVID-19 knowledge and have shown high risk perception of the 261 disease. This was significantly affected by social and media-related factors. This must 262 be taken into consideration when planning for effective risk communication. 263 Moreover, future studies should assess the effect of these factors on treatment-seeking 264 and vaccination should a vaccine be available. TABREF0.text: . A total of 486 pharmacists were enrolled in our study. Females pharmacists were dominant (78.6%) with around 50% holding bachelor's degree of pharmacy and 40.2 % working in a community or chain pharmacies. Around half of the participants had a monthly income of less than 700$ and 80% are living in urban areas.
